Award.AwardTitle: Speckle with Classical and Entangled Photons for Sensing, Imaging and Communication

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to investigate new ways of extracting and using information in optical speckle. Spatial diversity will be used for imaging and communication with optical speckle. The approach is to measure speckle patterns as a function of position and incorporate the data in a spatial intensity correlation model. Imaging with optical speckle suitable in a weakly scattering environment will be developed. The approach is to use a vector Bethe-Salpeter equation as the forward model. Imaging and communication with entangled photons in random scattering media will be studied. The approach is to use measurements of energy-time entangled photons in random scattering media, exploiting features of quantum entanglement.

Intellectual Merit

Methods to image within and through scattering media are important in the development of new clinical diagnostic tools, in environmental sensing within and through aerosols and emulsions, in material characterization, and in communication. The work will develop basic understanding, models for the scattering media, an imaging method suitable for weak and strong scatter, and characterization methods suitable for applications.

Broader Impacts

The work will impact applications with other segments of the electromagnetic spectrum, as well as other wave types. Two Ph.D. students will participate in the research, and an undergraduate student will be recruited each year. The work has the potential to impact elementary school science through the Purdue Engineering Projects in Community Service program, where undergraduate students are developing hands-on projects to teach important principles, and also provide demonstrations for the Women in Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF 1028610: Outcomes

Speckle with Classical and Entangled Photons for Sensing, Imaging and Communication

Kevin Webb, Purdue University

 Methods to image within and through scattering media are important in the development of new clinical diagnostic tools, in environmental sensing within and through aerosols and emulsions, in material characterization, and in communication. When coherent (laser) light scatters from random media, speckle forms. The statistics of speckle offer a wealth of information about the sources and the scattering medium. This project developed basic understanding about the random scatter of light, models for scattering media, an imaging method suitable for weak and heavy scatter, and characterization methods for applications.

 We developed a theory through which we are able to express the second order spatial speckle intensity correlation in terms of the Fourier spectrum of a field incident on a random medium. Using this model, we were able to extract the magnitude of the Fourier spectrum of the incident field using measured speckle intensity patterns and a phase retrieval method from speckle intensity measurements over incident field position through a heavily scattering medium. This work is fundamental to reconstructing the field incident on a random medium, impacting imaging and communication through scatter. Utilizing our speckle imaging theory, spatial speckle intensity correlations and iterative phase reconstructions we successfully reconstructed field images of a laser beam patterned by various apertures. Speckle images were collected on the transmission side of the randomly scattering media, which was excited by the patterned beam.

 We derived an analytical density function to model field statistics that is applicable to a variety of scattering regimes, from quasi-ballistic regime all the way to Anderson localization regime. Our result was obtained by assuming a random phasor sum model with a randomly varying number of contributing circular phasors. The validity of our density functions was verified through numerical simulations of electromagnetic waves propagating in 2D random media. Having a set of density functions that work in all scattering regimes provides a framework for modeling wave propagation in random media, facilitating random media characterization, imaging in and through scatter, and random laser design.

 We showed that spatial speckle correlations over moving object position could be used to detect and distinguish objects moving within heavily scattering media. Even if an object is hidden within an opaque material, its movement alone is enough to reveal it to an observer. We were able to separate the effects of random scatter from the deterministic motion of an object embedded within a scattering medium through the use of correlations of speckle images as a function of object position. We developed a method to image moving objects hidden within heavily scattering media and demonstrated the method for the example of an aperture. This imaging method should be important for in vivo applications and in environmental situations such as imaging in snow, through turbid water, and in aerosols.
